edu.missouri.bayesianConstructor

Class DomainKnowledge

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.missouri.bayesianConstructor.DomainKnowledge

  • public class DomainKnowledge
extends java.lang.Object
    Stores information pertinent to the domain knowledge. A domain knowledge is defined by a series of variables grouped into layers, with the dependence between any two layers being known. These dependence relations are stored in a directed acyclic graph and are called the domain knowledge's structure.

    The DomainKnowledge class exists to represent situations where a general relationship between broad concepts (variable layers) is known, but the relationship between the measurable elements of those concepts (the variables themselves) is not. The DomainKnowledge class therefore assumes that there is some relationship between all variables in the two layers, but that the strength of this relationship is stronger for some pairs of variables than others. The DomainKnowledge class allows storing these strengths numerically in dependency tables, but the values of these strengths must be computed by the caller. These relations can be discretized with the variableDependency(Double) function.

    A relationship where one layer D is known to depend on another I (denoted I→D) is called a dependence relation and is composed of the name or identifier for the layer depended on I—called the independent layer—and the layer D that depends on I—called the dependent layer. Note that these names are not absolute; any given layer is allowed to be dependent in one relation, and independent in another.

    The constructors initialize the instance with an empty graph. Layers are identified by means of a string referred to as the layer name. Layer names must be unique and are case sensitive. Variables are similarly identified by strings, but uniqueness is not enforced ( variableDependency(Double) will fail, though, if the variable names are not unique). Note however that the order of the variables does matter (for reasons explained below) and should not be altered wantoningly.

    Layers (vertices in the graph) may be added using the addLayer(String, List) method, retrieved with the getLayer(String) method, and removed with the removeLayer(String) method. The variables a layer is associated with can be modified with replaceLayer(String, List). Note, however, that the class cannot check if the order of the variables has changed, and therefore reinitializes the dependency table when this occurs to prevent bugs. Dependence between layers (graph edges) may be created using the addDependency(String, String) method. Note that this method enforces the acyclicity of the graph.

    Creation of a dependence relation creates a a dependency table storing the strength of this dependence. The dependency table for any existing relation may be accessed by calling getDependencyTable(String, String). The table can be filled by the caller and then reinserted into the instance using setDependency(String, String, Double[][]), which will attempt to ensure the right table is being associated with the right relation. These checks can be avoided by writing directly into the related table through an insecure access to dependencyTables. To see if a relationship exists, call containsDependency(String, String). To obtain all the relationships of a node, call getDependents(String) and getIndependents(String). Finally, dependence relations can be removed by calling removeDependency(String, String), which will also delete the data in the associated dependency table.

    A dependency table is a two-dimensional array containing one row for each variable in the independent layer and one column for each variable in the dependent layer. Thus, for a dependency table T representing the relationship I→D, the element in the jth row, kth column, stores how strongly the kth variable of D depends on the jth variable of I—that is, T[j][k] stores the strength of I.get(j)→D.get(k).

    Typical usage of this class will see the graph getting built, the dependency tables getting filled and finally a call to #variableDependency(Double), at which point the resulting graph between the variables can safely be used instead.

    Note that this class allows a layer to have zero variables, either by passing the empty list to it, or by setting its variable list to null. Consequently, if a dependency is created involving a layer with zero variables, the associated dependency table will have one of its dimensions set to zero. This is intended, to allow for "placeholder" layers (i.e. some future caller may need to compute the list of variables after creating the layer).

    This class uses the edu.ucla.structure library, which precedes generics and hence requires casting from Object and suppressing the resulting warning in Java 1.5 and above.

    Since:
    bayesianConstructor version 0.01
    Version:
    1.06 2016-04-19
    Author:
    Fernando J. Torre-Mora

      java.util.Map<edu.ucla.structure.DirectedEdge,java.lang.Double[][]> dependencyTables
      Stores the dependency tables indexed by relation.
      protected edu.ucla.structure.DirectedGraph layerStructure
      Stores the dependence relations between the layers; as such, the graph has one vertex for every layer and one edge for every relation.
      protected java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<java.lang.String>> layerVariables
      Stores the names of the variables associated with each layer, indexed by layer name.

    • Field Detail

      • layerStructure

        protected edu.ucla.structure.DirectedGraph layerStructure
        Stores the dependence relations between the layers; as such, the graph has one vertex for every layer and one edge for every relation.

      • layerVariables

        protected java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<java.lang.String>> layerVariables
        Stores the names of the variables associated with each layer, indexed by layer name. Note that layer names are case sensitive

      • dependencyTables

        public java.util.Map<edu.ucla.structure.DirectedEdge,java.lang.Double[][]> dependencyTables
        Stores the dependency tables indexed by relation. To access the desired dependency table, create a new DirectedEdge object E and use dependencyTables.get(E). (For instance, to access the dependency table of I→D, call dependencyTables.get(new DirectedEdge(I,D)))

    • Constructor Detail

      • DomainKnowledge

        public DomainKnowledge(int layers)
        Creates a new Domain Knowledge instance with an initial capacity for the specified number of layers. The capacity will grow dynamically if more layers are added
        Parameters:
        layers - the number of layers to be allocated as the initial capacity

      • DomainKnowledge

        public DomainKnowledge()
        Creates a new Domain Knowledge instance with an initial capacity for the default number of layers (3). The capacity will grow dynamically if more layers are added

    • Method Detail

      • layerInvariant

        protected boolean layerInvariant()
        Checks if the number of vertices in #layerStructure matches the number of layer names in #layerVariables. This check should be performed every time the layers are changed.
        Returns:
        true if there are exactly as many nodes in the graph as there are layers; false otherwise

      • dependencyInvariant

        protected boolean dependencyInvariant()
        Checks if there is a dependency table for each relationship This check should be performed every time a relationship is added or removed.
        Returns:
        true if there are exactly as many dependency tables as there are dependency relationships; false otherwise

      • variableInvariant

        protected boolean variableInvariant()
        Checks if the dependency tables are the right size. This check should be performed every time a dependency table is initialized or replaced
        Returns:
        true if each dependency table has exactly as many rows as there are variables in the independent layer, and exactly as many columns as there are variables in the dependent layer, of the corresponding dependency relationship; false otherwise.

      • t

        protected int t(int n)
        Obtains the total number of elements that would result from adding the given value, plus all the numbers less than it. This is especially useful for predicting the minimum number of connections we can expect to occur between n variables
        Parameters:
        n - the number of elements to add
        Returns:
        ⌊n×(n-1)÷2⌋

                                                 java.lang.String dependent)

        Parameters:
        independent - the name of the layer that dependent depends on
        dependent - the name of the layer that depends on independent
        Returns:
        the previously-stored dependency table, or null if no previous table exists
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if either one of the layers does not exist

                                java.lang.String dependent)
                         throws java.lang.SecurityException
        Checks if the given edge creates a cycle and if so, removes it and throws an exception

        dependent - the name of the layer that depends on independent
        Throws:

      • addDependency

        public boolean addDependency(java.lang.String independent,
                             java.lang.String dependent)
                      throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                             java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                             java.lang.SecurityException
        Adds a dependency relationship from the independent layer specified, to the dependent layer specified initialized with an empty table in dependencyTables. Note that this does not initialize any of its cells.

        The method requires the new dependency to keep the graph acyclic and will roll back any changes if this is not the case.

        Parameters:
        independent - the name of the layer that dependent depends on
        dependent - the name of the layer that depends on independent
        Returns:
        true if a dependency was created
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if either one of the layers does not exist
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a relationship between the layers already exists
        java.lang.SecurityException - if adding the edge results in a cycle being created

      • rightSize

        private void rightSize(java.lang.String independent,
                       java.lang.String dependent,
                       java.lang.Double[][] dependencyTable)
                throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Checks if the given dependency table is the right size for the independent→dependent relation
        Parameters:
        independent - the name of the layer that dependent depends on
        dependent - the name of the layer that depends on independent
        dependencyTable - the new values for the dependency table of the relationship between independent and dependent
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the dependency table provided does not have enough entries for each dimension, or if the rows of dependencyTable are of different length

      • addDependency

        public boolean addDependency(java.lang.String independent,
                             java.lang.String dependent,
                             java.lang.Double[][] dependencyTable)
                      throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                             java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                             java.lang.SecurityException
        Adds a dependency relationship from the independent layer specified, to the dependent layer specified initialized with the specified dependencyTable.

        The method requires the new dependency to keep the graph acyclic and will roll back any changes if this is not the case.

        Parameters:
        independent - the name of the layer that dependent depends on
        dependent - the name of the layer that depends on independent
        dependencyTable - the new values for the dependency table of the relationship between independent and dependent
        Returns:
        true if a dependency was created
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if either one of the layers does not exist, if the dependency table provided does not have enough entries for each dimension, or if the rows of dependencyTable are of different length
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a relationship between the layers already exists
        java.lang.SecurityException - if adding the edge results in a cycle being created

      • containsDependency

        public boolean containsDependency(java.lang.String independent,
                                  java.lang.String dependent)
        Indicates whether a dependency relation exists between the given layers
        Parameters:
        independent - Name of the layer it is desired to see if dependent depends on
        dependent - Name of the layer it is desired to see depends on independent
        Returns:
        true if a relationship exists where dependent depends on independent; false if the independent→dependent

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • getDependencyTable

        public java.lang.Double[][] getDependencyTable(java.lang.String independent,
                                               java.lang.String dependent)
        Gets the dependency table for the relation independent→ dependent
        Parameters:
        independent - Name of the layer dependent depends on in the desired relation
        dependent - Name of the layer that depends on independent in the desired relation
        Returns:
        A table with the dependence values for every variable in independent (row) and dependent (column) or null if the relation independent→ dependent does not exist

      • removeDependency

        public java.lang.Double[][] removeDependency(java.lang.String independent,
                                             java.lang.String dependent)
        Removes a dependency relationship from the independent layer specified, to the dependent layer specified.
        Parameters:
        independent - the name of the layer that dependent no longer depends on
        dependent - the name of the layer that no longer depends on independent
        Returns:
        the dependency table removed when the edge was removed, or null if the relationship didn't exist

      • replaceLayer

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> replaceLayer(java.lang.String layerName,
                                                     java.util.List<java.lang.String> layerVariables)
                                              throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Updates the list of variables associated to the given layer. Note that this will cause the dependency tables related to that layer to be reinitialized
        Parameters:
        layerName - the name of the layer to be replaced
        layerVariables - the new list of variables for this layer
        Returns:
        the previous list of variables associated with the specified layerName
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if no layer with that name exists

      • setDependency

        public java.lang.Double[][] setDependency(java.lang.String independent,
                                          java.lang.String dependent,
                                          java.lang.Double[][] dependencyTable)
                                   throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                          java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Updates the dependency table between the given layers to the given table.
        Parameters:
        independent - the name of the layer that dependent depends on
        dependent - the name of the layer that depends on independent
        dependencyTable - the new values for the dependency table of the relationship between independent and dependent
        Returns:
        the dependency table with the previous values
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if either one of the layers does not exist, if the dependency table provided does not have enough entries for each dimension, or if the rows of dependencyTable are of different length
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the layers exist but the relationship between them has not been created

      • variableDependency

        public edu.ucla.structure.DirectedGraph variableDependency(java.lang.Double threshold)
                                                    throws java.lang.NullPointerException
        Gets the relationships represented between all the variables of all the layers. Note that to perform this conversion, the same variable name can't appear in two different layers or indeed in the same layer
        Parameters:
        threshold - Minimum dependency strength in dependencyTables for the variables to be considered related
        Returns:
        a graph where each vertex is a variable and each arc indicates if there's a dependence between them greater than or equal to the threshold. The graph is guaranteed to be acyclic.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any one of the dependencyTables' cells have not been initialized
        Since:
        1.01 2016-03-14

      • variableDependency

        public edu.ucla.structure.DirectedGraph variableDependency()
                                                    throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                                                           java.lang.NullPointerException
        Gets the relationships represented between all the variables of all the layers assuming the default threshold of zero (any positive number is sufficient). Note that to perform this conversion, the same variable name can't appear in two different layers or indeed in the same layer
        Returns:
        a graph where each vertex is a variable and each arc indicates if there's a positive dependence between them. The graph is guaranteed to be acyclic
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the variable names are not unique
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any one of the dependencyTables' cells have not been initialized
        Since:
        1.01 2016-03-14

      • tddTest

        private void tddTest(int layers)
              throws java.lang.AssertionError
        Tests the class' correctness for the given number of layers. Each layer is created with as many variables as the layer name (thus, layer 0 has zero variables, layer 1 has one, etc).
        Parameters:
        layers - Number of layers to run the test with
        Throws:
        java.lang.AssertionError - if any of the checks fail

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
                 throws java.lang.AssertionError
        Performs a full correctness test to ensure the class is working correctly
        Parameters:
        args - (ignored)
        Throws:
        java.lang.AssertionError - if the correctness test fails
